query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 Lì si cantò non Bacco, non Peana, 26 ma tre persone in divina natura, 27 e in una persona essa e l’umana.
query.result: 25 There was sung not Bacchus, not Paean, 26 but three persons in divine nature, 27 and in one person it and the human.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Compié ’l cantare e ’l volger sua misura; 29 e attesersi a noi quei santi lumi, 30 felicitando sé di cura in cura.

Please translate each line literally into English.
31 Ruppe il silenzio ne’ concordi numi 32 poscia la luce in che mirabil vita 33 del poverel di Dio narrata fumi,
34 e disse: «Quando l’una paglia è trita, 35 quando la sua semenza è già riposta, 36 a batter l’altra dolce amor m’invita.
query.result:
31 Broke the silence the harmonious gods 32 then the light in which marvelous life 33 of the poor one of God narrated smoked,
34 and said: «When the one straw is crushed, 35 when its seed is already laid to rest, 36 to beat the other sweet love invites me.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 Tu credi che nel petto onde la costa 38 si trasse per formar la bella guancia 39 il cui palato a tutto ’l mondo costa,
40 e in quel che, forato da la lancia, 41 e prima e poscia tanto sodisfece, 42 che d’ogne colpa vince la bilancia,
43 quantunque a la natura umana lece 44 aver di lume, tutto fosse infuso 45 da quel valor che l’uno e l’altro fece;
46 e però miri a ciò ch’io dissi suso, 47 quando narrai che non ebbe ’l secondo 48 lo ben che ne la quinta luce è chiuso.
query.result:
37 You believe that in the chest where the rib 38 was drawn to form the beautiful cheek 39 whose palate costs everything to the world,
40 and in that which, pierced by the lance, 41 and before and after so satisfied, 42 that of every fault it overcomes the balance,
43 however much it is permitted to human nature 44 to have of light, all was infused 45 by that valor that the one and the other made;
46 and therefore look to what I said above, 47 when I narrated that the second did not have 48 the good that is closed in the fifth light.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Or apri li occhi a quel ch’io ti rispondo, 50 e vedräi il tuo credere e ’l mio dire 51 nel vero farsi come centro in tondo.
query.result: 49 Now open your eyes to what I respond to you, 50 and you will see your believing and my saying 51 becoming true like a center in a circle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Ciò che non more e ciò che può morire 53 non è se non splendor di quella idea 54 che partorisce, amando, il nostro Sire;
55 ché quella viva luce che sì mea 56 dal suo lucente, che non si disuna 57 da lui né da l’amor ch’a lor s’intrea,
58 per sua bontate il suo raggiare aduna, 59 quasi specchiato, in nove sussistenze, 60 etternalmente rimanendosi una.

query.result:
61 From there it descends to the ultimate powers 62 down from act to act, so becoming, 63 that it makes no more than brief contingencies;
64 and these contingencies I understand to be 65 the generated things, which it produces 66 with seed and without seed by moving the heaven.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
67 La cera di costoro e chi la duce 68 non sta d’un modo; e però sotto ’l segno 69 idëale poi più e men traluce.
query.result: 67 The wax of these and he who leads it 68 does not stay in one way; and therefore under the sign 69 ideal then more and less shines through.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
70 Ond’ elli avvien ch’un medesimo legno, 71 secondo specie, meglio e peggio frutta; 72 e voi nascete con diverso ingegno.

query.result:
73 If the wax were at its point of being consumed 74 and the sky were in its highest power, 75 the light of the seal would appear all;
76 but nature gives it always deficient, 77 similarly operating to the artist 78 who to the habit of art has a hand that trembles.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Però se ’l caldo amor la chiara vista 80 de la prima virtù dispone e segna, 81 tutta la perfezion quivi s’acquista.
query.result: 79 Therefore if the warm love the clear sight 80 of the first virtue disposes and marks, 81 all the perfection is acquired there.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
88 Or s’i’ non procedesse avanti piùe, 89 ‘Dunque, come costui fu sanza pare?’ 90 comincerebber le parole tue.
query.result: 88 Now if I did not proceed further, 89 “Therefore, how was this one without equal?” 90 would your words begin.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Ma perché paia ben ciò che non pare, 92 pensa chi era, e la cagion che ’l mosse, 93 quando fu detto “Chiedi”, a dimandare.
query.result: 91 But because it may seem good what does not seem, 92 think who he was, and the cause that moved him, 93 when it was said “Ask”, to ask.

103 Wherefore, if what I said and this you note, 104 royal prudence is that seeing unequal 105 in which the dart of my intention strikes;
106 and if to the “arise” you lift your clear eyes, 107 you will see to have only respect 108 to kings, who are many, and the good are rare.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Con questa distinzion prendi ’l mio detto; 110 e così puote star con quel che credi 111 del primo padre e del nostro Diletto.

Please translate each line literally into English.
112 E questo ti sia sempre piombo a’ piedi, 113 per farti mover lento com’ uom lasso 114 e al sì e al no che tu non vedi:
115 ché quelli è tra li stolti bene a basso, 116 che sanza distinzione afferma e nega 117 ne l’un così come ne l’altro passo;
118 perch’ elli ’ncontra che più volte piega 119 l’oppinïon corrente in falsa parte, 120 e poi l’affetto l’intelletto lega.

Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Vie più che ’ndarno da riva si parte, 122 perché non torna tal qual e’ si move, 123 chi pesca per lo vero e non ha l’arte.
query.result: 121 Far more than in vain from the shore one departs, 122 because does not return such as he moves, 123 who fishes for the truth and does not have the art.

124 And of this there are open proofs in the world 125 Parmenides, Melissus and Bissus and many, 126 who went and did not know where;
127 thus did Sabellius and Arius and those fools 128 who were like swords to the Scriptures 129 in rendering twisted the right faces.

139 Let not lady Berta and sir Martino believe, 140 to see a hole, to offer something else, 141 to see them inside the divine counsel;
142 because that can rise, and that can fall.
